[[Image:Efez Celsus Library 3 RB.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Personification]] of wisdom (in [[Greek language|Greek]], "''Σοφία''" or "''[[Sophia (wisdom)|Sophia]]''") at the [[Celsus Library]] in [[Ephesus]], [[Turkey]].]]
 
[[Image:Efez Celsus Library 3 RB.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Personification]] of wisdom (in [[Greek language|Greek]], "''Σοφία''" or "''[[Sophia (wisdom)|Sophia]]''") at the [[Celsus Library]] in [[Ephesus]], [[Turkey]].]]
−   −        
'''Wisdom''' is a deep understanding and realizing of people, things, events or situations, resulting in the ability to choose or act or inspire to consistently produce the optimum results with a minimum of time, energy or thought. It is the ability to optimally (effectively and efficiently) apply perceptions and knowledge and so produce the desired results. Wisdom is also the comprehension of what is true or right coupled with optimum judgment as to action. Synonyms include: sagacity, discernment, or insight. Wisdom often requires control of one's emotional reactions (the "passions") so that one's principles, reason and knowledge prevail to determine one's actions.
 
'''Wisdom''' is a deep understanding and realizing of people, things, events or situations, resulting in the ability to choose or act or inspire to consistently produce the optimum results with a minimum of time, energy or thought. It is the ability to optimally (effectively and efficiently) apply perceptions and knowledge and so produce the desired results. Wisdom is also the comprehension of what is true or right coupled with optimum judgment as to action. Synonyms include: sagacity, discernment, or insight. Wisdom often requires control of one's emotional reactions (the "passions") so that one's principles, reason and knowledge prevail to determine one's actions.
Line 21: Line 19:  
== Psychological perspectives ==
 
== Psychological perspectives ==
 
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social [[Psychology]], 49, 607–62.</ref>
 
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social [[Psychology]], 49, 607–62.</ref>
−
These analyses indicate that although "there is an overlap of the implicit theory of wisdom with intelligence, perceptiveness, spirituality and shrewdness, it is evident that wisdom is a distinct term and not a composite of other terms."<ref>Brown, S. C., & Greene, J. A. (2006). The Wisdom Development Scale: Translating the conceptual to the concrete. Journal of College Student Development, 47, 1–19.</ref> Many, but not all, studies find that adults' self-ratings of perspective/wisdom do not depend on age.<ref name="CSVperspective" /><ref name="Orwoll">{{cite book|last=Orwoll|first=L.|coauthors=Perlmutter, M.|title=Wisdom: Its nature, origins, and development|editor=R. J. Sternberg|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|year=1990|pages=160–177|isbn=0521367182}}</ref> This stands in contrast to the popular notion that wisdom increases with age<ref name="Orwoll" />, supported by a recent study showing that regardless of their education, IQ or gender, older adults possess superior reasoning about societal and interpersonal conflicts<ref name=Grossmann>{{cite journal|last=Grossmann|first=Igor|coauthors=Jinkyung Na, Michael E W. Varnum, Denise C. Park, Shinobu Kitayama, Richard E. Nisbett|title=Reasoning about social conflicts improves into old age|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|year=2010|volume=107|issue=16|pages=7246–7250|doi=10.1073/pnas.1001715107|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2010/03/23/1001715107|accessdate=1 May 2011}}</ref>. In many cultures the name for third molars, which are the last teeth to grow, is etymologically linked with wisdom, e.g. as in the English ''[[wisdom tooth]]''. In 2009, a study reviewed which brain processes might be related to wisdom.<ref>[http://archpsyc.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/66/4/355 Neurobiology of Wisdom: A Literature Overview].</ref>
+

Line 56: Line 54:  
[[Saa]] represents the personification of wisdom or the God of wisdom in Ancient Egyptian Mythology.
 
[[Saa]] represents the personification of wisdom or the God of wisdom in Ancient Egyptian Mythology.
    −
=== [[Hebrew Bible]] ===
+
=== Hebrew Bible ===
 
{{unclear section|date=December 2010}}
 
{{unclear section|date=December 2010}}
 
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] scripture, wisdom is represented by the sense of justice of the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in [[2 Chronicles]] 1. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In Proverbs 1:7 and 9:10, the [[Fear of the lord|fear of the Lord]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while Proverbs 8:13 declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In Proverbs 1:20, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares." Continuing in Proverbs 8:22-31, this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself, delighting especially in human beings.
 
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] scripture, wisdom is represented by the sense of justice of the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in [[2 Chronicles]] 1. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In Proverbs 1:7 and 9:10, the [[Fear of the lord|fear of the Lord]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while Proverbs 8:13 declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In Proverbs 1:20, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares." Continuing in Proverbs 8:22-31, this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself, delighting especially in human beings.
